sentence: Stocks in the US closed higher on Monday, with energy shares leading gains among the S&P 500 sectors and on the Dow Jones Industrial Average as US benchmark oil futures rallied to their best levels in about 15 months.
Nine of the 11 S&P groups were higher, led by a 1.5% increase in energy.
The Dow's top gainers included Chevron ( CVX ) and Exxon Mobil ( XOM ).

Crude rallied on speculation that members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries will come to an agreement to curb production this week in the first of several reported gatherings to hammer out details of an agreement made in Algiers last month.
Also, Russian President Vladimir Putin said Monday his country may be willing to freeze or cut production.
West Texas Intermediate rose 2.8% to $51.20 a barrel, the highest since July 2015.

Stocks also got a lift from last night's presidential debate between Republican candidate Donald Trump and Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton as Wall Street seems more at ease with the more defined economic policies of front-runner Clinton than the uncertainty surrounding Trump.

Later in the week, investors will turn to the economic agenda, with the Wednesday release of minutes from the last Federal Open Market Committee Meeting and a number of speeches and comments due to come from Fed officials.
Also, the start of quarterly earnings will take the stage, with Alcoa ( AA ) due to report results on Tuesday in what's usually seen as the launch of the season.

Here's where the markets stood by the close:

(+) EGAS (+64.7%) Sold to First Reserve for $13.10 per share

(+) XGTI (+7.3%) Says Integrated Microwave buy brings in more than $2 million in annual cost savings

(-) TWLO (-14.1%) Plans to sell up to $400 million of class A shares

(-) TWTR (-11.5%) Salesforce ( CRM ), Disney ( DIS ), Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) reportedly no longer interested in an acquisition

(-) BMY (-10.1%) Reported updated results from two phase 2 studies of Opdivo for treatment of lung cancer

(-) DOV (-7.7%%) Lowers FY sales guidance to -4% to -5% from down 3% to down 5%.

(-) OPTT (-9.3%) To offer up to 2.87 million shares in public offering
